blocks.html: Frank Elderson
Member of the Executive Board
[COURTESY TRANSLATION]
Mr Richard Raši Speaker of the National Council of the Slovak Republic National Council of the Slovak Republic Námestie Alexandra Dubčeka 1 812 80 Bratislava 1 SLOVAKIA
Frankfurt am Main, 10 February 2026
Contact person: mikulas.prokop@ecb.europa.eu
Re: Amendments to the Law on restrictions on cash payments
Dear Mr Raši,

It has come to the attention of the European Central Bank (ECB) that on 3 December 2025 the National Council of the Slovak Republic adopted a Law on the registration of sales and on amendments to certain laws1 (hereinafter the 'Law').

The Law amends, among others, the Law on restrictions on cash payments2 by introducing a prohibition of (a) cash payments in excess of EUR 5 000 by or from legal persons or natural persons who are entrepreneurs; and (b) cash payments in excess of EUR 15 000 between natural persons who are not entrepreneurs.

On 26 September 2025 the ECB adopted an opinion on an earlier draft version of the Law, which concerned the mandatory acceptance of cashless payments by sellers3. The ECB understands that after the adoption of that opinion, in the legislative process at the National Council of the Slovak Republic and following a resolution of the Committee of the National Council of the Slovak Republic for Finance and Budget4, the Law was further amended to introduce also the amendments to the Law on restrictions on cash payments described above. Therefore, the ECB was not consulted on these amendments to the law on restrictions on cash payments.
Sonnemannstrasse 20 60640 Frankfurt am Main E-mail: info@ecb.europa.eu
1 Zákon č. 384/2025 Z.z. o evidencii tržieb a o zmene a doplnení niektorých zákonov.
2 Zákon č. 394/2012 Z.z. o obmedzení platieb v hotovosti.
3 See Opinion CON/2025/30. All ECB opinions are published on EUR-Lex.
4 Uznesenie Výboru Národnej rady Slovenskej republiky pre financie a rozpočet z 19. novembra 2025, Číslo: KNR-VFR-6045/2025-5.

In accordance with Articles 127(4) and 282(5) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and Article 2(1) of Council Decision 98/415/EC5 national authorities are required to consult the ECB on draft legislative provisions concerning matters that fall within its fields of competence, including means of payment.

In addition, Article 80(1) of Regulation (EU) 2024/1624 of the European Parliament and of the Council6 sets a cash payment and acceptance limit of EUR 10 000 for persons trading in goods or providing services. Article 80(2) of the same Regulation allows Member States to adopt lower limits following consultation of the ECB in accordance with Article 2(1) of Decision 98/415/EC7.

While the ECB adopted an opinion on an earlier version of the Law, this does not release the Slovak authorities from their duty to reconsult the ECB in accordance with the Treaty and Decision 98/415/EC. As noted in the ECB Guide to consultation of the European Central Bank by national authorities regarding draft legislative provisions8, the obligation to consult the ECB on amendments to draft legislative provisions which have already been submitted to the ECB for an opinion applies to substantive amendments which affect the essence of the draft legislation. Where substantive new provisions are proposed after the ECB opinion has been adopted, by analogy to the Court's case-law on the requirement to reconsult Union institutions on amended draft legislation9, the ECB should be reconsulted in relation to those amendments in exceptional cases where the draft legislation has undergone substantial changes of a non-technical nature as compared to the version on which the ECB has previously been consulted. The ECB considers that the amendments to the Law on restrictions on cash payments represent substantial changes of a nontechnical nature compared to the version of the Law on which the ECB had previously been consulted, which concerned the separate topic of the mandatory acceptance of cashless payments.

While the ECB adopted an opinion in 2012 when the Law on restrictions on cash payments was adopted10, and while said Law on restrictions on cash payments included the same limits as those re-introduced by the Law at the time of adoption, this does not release the Slovak authorities from their duty to consult the ECB in accordance with the Treaty and Decision 98/415/EC, in particular given the substantial development in the jurisprudence on the restrictions on cash payments following the decision of the Court of Justice of the European Union in 2021 in the Hessischer Rundfunk case11. In this respect, the ECB would like to draw

5 Council Decision 98/415/EC of 29 June 1998 on the consultation of the European Central Bank by national authorities regarding draft legislative provisions (OJ L 189, 3.7.1998, p. 42, ELI: http://data.europa.eu/eli/dec/1998/415/oj).

6 Regulation (EU) 2024/1624 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 31 May 2024 on the prevention of the use of the financial system for the purposes of money laundering or terrorist financing (OJ L 2024/1624, 19.6.2024, ELI: http://data.europa.eu/eli/reg/2024/1624/oj).

7 Article 80(2) of Regulation (EU) 2024/1624: '"Member States may adopt lower limits following consultation of the European Central Bank in accordance with Article 2(1) of Council Decision 98/415/EC. Those lower limits shall be notified to the Commission within 3 months of the measure being introduced at national level.'"
8 See European Central Bank, Guide to consultation of the European Central Bank by national authorities regarding draft legislative provisions (April 2025), p. 12, available at www.ecb.europa.eu.

9 See Judgment of the Court of Justice of 15 July 1970, Chemiefarma v Commission, C-41/69, ECLI:EU:C:1970:71, paragraph 3; judgment of the Court of 4 February 1982, Buyl and Others v Commission, C-817/79, ECLI:EU:C:1982:36, paragraph 1; judgment of the Court of Justice of 10 June 1997, Parliament v Council, C-392/95, ECLI:EU:C:1997:289, paragraph 15; judgment of the Court of Justice of 11 November 1997, Eurotunnel and Others v SeaFrance, C-408/95, ECLI:EU:C:1997:532, paragraph 46; judgment of the Court of 25 September 2003, Océ van der Grinten, C-58/01, ECLI:EU:C:2003:495, paragraphs 100 and 102.
10 See Opinion CON/2012/83.
11 See judgment of the Court (Grand Chamber) of 26 January 2021, Hessischer Rundfunk, C-422/19 and C-423/19, ECLI:EU:C:2021:63.

the attention of the Slovak authorities to certain opinions adopted by the ECB since 2021 concerning general cash limitations and cash payments12, including, in particular, an opinion adopted by the ECB in 2023 in response to a consultation by the Chairman of the Financial and Budgetary Committee of the National Council of the Slovak Republic on a draft law amending the Law on restrictions on cash payments, in particular on increasing the applicable cash payment limits at that time13.

The ECB would appreciate that the National Council gives due consideration to the above observations by honouring its obligation to consult the ECB in the future on draft national legislation falling within the ECB's fields of competence where appropriate.
Yours sincerely,
[signed]
Cc: Mr P Kažimír, Governor, Národná banka Slovenska
Mr L Kamenický, Ministerstvo financií Slovenskej republiky
Mr V Dombrovskis, Commissioner for Economy and Productivity; Implementation and Simplification, European Commission
Mr A De Gregorio Merino, Director-General Legal Service, European Commission
Encl. Guide to consultation of the ECB by national authorities regarding draft legislative provisions
12 See, for example, Opinions CON/2022/9 (Spain), CON/2023/33 (Belgium), CON/2023/40 (Belgium), CON/2024/2 (Denmark) and CON/2024/39 (Netherlands).
13 See Opinion CON/2023/13.
